name: The Big Pink
description:
Introduction

A long approach with a technical section. Its Big and its Pink rock.

  • Do not place bolts in this or any of the canyons within the Lake Mead NRA.

Approach

We used the approach from Arizona Hot Springs and found a break into the hills once we got near the hot springs. Mining material was spotted along the way. The route requires a bit of route finding so make sure you drop into the right drainage.

Descent

The first rappel is around 60 ft. rap with an overhang. The anchorage is a Deadman with webbing and a rapide. You will find a few downclimbs and all to quickly the last rap will show up. A large boulder and webbing is used for the anchorage down a 150 ft rap to the river. You can fit 6-7 people on the slab rock and there is a nice pool to cure your raft and a nice place to jump in too cool off before your paddle upstream. We used the AZ hot springs exit. If weather will not permit a upstream exit, use the big horn exit.

Exit

Exit using the Arizona Hot Spring trail.

Red tape

you must use a USCG approved watercraft, and PFD. Do not place bolts in the canyon. There is plenty of material to rebuild anchorage systems just bring webbing and rapides. If weather doesn't permit a AZ hot springs (upriver right) exit than exit Big Horn Canyon (down river right) make sure you have a shuttle car at the exit trailhead of bighorn.

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

EVEN FURTHER-THE BIG PINK

Background

A canyon that appears to have been visited by miners back in the prospecting days, but no other anchorage material was noticed. For the region, this has a long approach and only 2 raps with some downclimbs. The last rappel is scenic with nice views of the river and weeping springs.
